messages.content: Hello (:flower) I'm <PERSON>. This is your safe space to share whatever's in your heart. How are you holding up today?
I lost my grandmother two months ago. I still cry almost every night. (:sad)
I'm so sorry for your loss. Losing someone close can feel like a hole in your world. Grief has no timeline—it comes in waves. When those tears come, what do you feel you're missing most about her?
Her voice. She used to call me every evening, and now the silence is unbearable.

That silence must be incredibly heavy. She brought warmth and routine to your life. Sometimes holding onto small rituals—like writing her a letter or listening to a song she loved—can help ease the ache.
I even found her old email, <EMAIL>. I typed a message but didn’t send it. I don’t know why.
That shows how much you long for connection. Even drafting the email is a way of expressing your feelings. Maybe the act of writing itself is healing, even if you never send it.
Maybe I keep imagining her telling me "It's okay, I'm proud of you" before she passed. It hurts so much.

That imagined reassurance reflects your need for closure and love. Sometimes grief lingers because we wish we had said or heard certain things. What if you try giving yourself those words now—what would you say to her in your heart?
I'd say "I love you and miss you so much. Thank you for everything." (:heart)
Beautiful. That message can be a small bridge between you and her memory. Writing it down or speaking it out loud can help you feel closer.
I tried listening to her favorite song on <URL>, but it made me cry more. (:sad)
Music can open the floodgates of emotion. That's okay—tears are part of healing. Sometimes feeling the sadness fully allows it to gradually soften.
I also feel guilty. I didn't visit her last month when I had the chance because I was busy with university.
Guilt is a natural response, but remember your intentions mattered, even if circumstances got in the way. She knew you loved her. Our actions are not always perfect, but love persists.
Yeah, but it's hard. My cousin <PERSON> keeps saying I should be over it by now.

That pressure can make grief even heavier. Everyone experiences loss differently. What you feel is valid, and there’s no timetable. Would it help to set boundaries around conversations about your grief?
Maybe I also found a photo album from <DATE> with her in it. Seeing her smile made me want to hug her again.
Photos are powerful reminders of the joy she brought. You can honor that memory by recalling the moments that made you happy together, even if you can’t physically hug her.
Sometimes I dream about her. Last night she was sitting under a tree and smiling at me.
Dreams can be comforting or painful; they let us feel close to lost loved ones. That vision under the tree sounds serene. How did it make you feel when you woke up?
Sad but also a little happy. Like she was telling me "I'm still here in your heart."
Exactly. Those moments can remind you that love endures even after loss. Maybe you could write down these dreams in a journal to keep her presence alive in your memory.
I also miss her advice. She used to say "Life is about small joys" whenever I felt stressed.
Holding onto her words can guide you now. Perhaps whenever you feel overwhelmed, you can silently repeat her advice. It’s like having her wisdom close by.
I think I'll start a little ritual. Light a candle every Sunday at <TIME> and talk to her in my mind. (:candle)

That’s a beautiful ritual. It honors her memory while giving you a safe space to process your emotions. Even small actions like this can help integrate grief into your life rather than letting it weigh you down.
Thank you, <PERSON>. I feel a bit lighter talking to you. Maybe I can even finish the email I started to <EMAIL> one day, just for myself.
Absolutely. The act of writing can be its own form of closure. You’re doing something brave—facing grief and finding ways to connect with her memory.
